DN_notes_on_Vieira-Silva_edits: Faster doubling time chosen from different strain.
Highest growth rate reported 0.33h-1 = 2.1h doubling time

Lack of ref to data source in paper, only mentions growth rates (0.115 / h). Also, in referenced study organism is grown on n-hexadecane which does not support maximum growth rate. Alternative reference uses more appropriate carbon source resulting in much faster growth rate.
The reported rate is under added fructose - wihtout it, growth rates are 16h at high CO2 and 24h at normal CO2 levels.
No growth data shown.
A slightly lower doubling time (1.8h) was observed using elemental sulphur
Not primary source. Primary source retrieved.
Could not find the doubling time as reported by Silva. Growth rate denoted as 00·57 h-1.Assumed  0.57 h-1

Not same species (Azoarcus tolulyticus) - which has recently been sequenced. See Kniemeyer & Heider 2001 - they don't show the growth data but mentions max doubling time in results. See also Rabus & widdle 1995 for doubling time (11h) on ethylbenzene. This microbe is generally only grown with obscure aromatic compounds, so doubling time is probably underestimated. Azoarcus sp EbN1 has  changed name to Aromatoleum aromaticum.
Unclear if the reported doubling time is a result of bacterial growth  or rate of internalisation of spores in macropahges.
Not primary source. Primary source retrieved.
Not same organism. Unable to find data on B. halodurans
Could not find the doubling time as reported. Only a proxi was reported for a different strain. New source retrieved.

It appears doubling time is not calculated correctly. A growth rate of 1.59/h is reported and a doubling time of 37.7 min, which equates to 60/1.59. If calculated as standard the reported growth rate equates to 0.44h or 26 min

Cannot find reported doubling time as reported by Silva. Doubling time calculated based on  limited info: "The number of viable cells increased
approximately eightfold in 24 hr". This microbe has changed name from Rickettsia quintana
Could not find the doubling time as reported by Silva. New source retrieved.
Could not retrieve paper but doubling time reported in abstract. Fast initial growth in nymph which later slows down.

Not correct species. Oliveira et al.2010 uses various media to study growth of this bacteria and reports growth curves equivalent to a doubling time of about 100h. This seems unrealistic given the much faster growth of its close relative - and particularly the much faster growth observed of burgdorferi in vivo during initial inocculation of a tick. Hence, unless we get better data for this species, I suggest we exclude it.
Could not retrieve ref which also doesn't seem appropriate. New primary source retrieved.

Bergeys manual, cannot locate primary data on B. floridanus
Reference to a PHD thesis which could not be readily obtained.
Not primary source. Primary source retrieved.
Supposed rounding error.

Bergeys manual. Can't find alternative. NOTE: 24h doubling rate for Chlamydia does not seem correct. This likely includes the whole generational cycle which in itself includes a long lag phase in which non-replicating "EB" cells are taken up by the host cell and redifferentiate into "RB" cells - which can actively replicate. This lag phase is often in the order of 20h. The doubling rate of "RB" cells, once ready to divide, is much higher than reported here - and for multiple strains of C. trachomatis reported to be between 2 and 4 hours (mentioned in Wang et al.2007). Miyiri et al.2006 reports doubling times of 2-3h for multiple strains of C. trachomatis. C. psittaci has been shown to have a doubling time of 2h (Alexander JJ 1969). In a review on Chlamydia by McClarty 1994, RB doubling times is reported to generally be in the range of 2h.
Bergeys manual. Primary source retrieved.

While this paper is actually on a different species, it does contain data on the specified species.
The indicated growth rate is based on  maximum dilution rate in chemostat and so may be an underestimation.

Not primary source. Primary source retrieved.  - and the current reference refers to another review for source of doubling time: Baca, O.G. and Paretsky, D. (1983) Microbiol. Rev. 47, 127–149. Altarnative reference refer to an old study where calculation of Ld50 data gives a doubling time of 8.8h, but I can't follow the calculation and therefore stick with the current estimate. This seems to be in the low end of what is generally guestimated in the litterature for this species.
Growth data not shown - only mention of doubling time
Doubling time is mean of multiple strains with very similar doubling times. Enterobacter sakazakii has changed name to Cronobacter sakazakii
Wrong species - Enterococcus faecium.

Not convinced by the quality of the referenced paper. No indication of whether organism is grown aerobically - and indicated growth rate seems very high - even compared  to their data figures. I have recorded data from  a different study (average of multiple strains read from figure: approx 0.3/h). This  number seems to fit better with the graph of the original reference. Erwinia carotovora atroseptica has changed name to Pectobacterium atrosepticum.
Not primary source. Primary source retrieved.
Douling time a very rough estimate based on two datapoints over 18h
Doubling time does not appear to have been calculated correctly. A growth rate of 1.48/h is reported for this organism, which equates to a doubling time of 0.47 hours.

The referenced paper/data relates to co-culturing conditions, which may not be appropriate for minimal growth rate estimiates of G sulfurreducens. However, other papers seem to have similar growth rates or slower, so let's go with this.

Calculation of the critical dilution rate (0.62 h-1) corresponding to the maximal growth rate was done by the method of Pirt and Callow. Note, the value repoted by Silva corresponds to 1/0.62=1.63. This is not correct.

Bergeys manual. Primary source retrieved. Note: No primary data could be found in primary sources supporting a doubling rate at 8h. All  references found mentioning this doubling time refered to the same section in Bergey's. No supporting data could be found in papers from the authors of this chapter in Bergey's. Most reported doubling rates are much higher, and the one chosen here represents the second shortest doubling rate found for N. winogradskyi. However, the faster doubling rate (calculated from figure to just under 14h, was from a paper [Laudelout &  Fripiat 1974] with very limited information and no info on strain used).

Ref in Japanese. Use alternative - Doubling time reported in Beckers is supported by other papers - generally just over 1h per generation. However, I also found a non-published study reporting doubling times of 43 minutes in TSB media (Schell et al.poster). Supporting the 0.75 doubling time reported by Silva.
